title: How to Allow iCloud to Use Cellular Data for Transfers on an iPhone

steps.title: Open your iPhone’s Settings .
steps.content: Open your iPhone’s Settings . This is the grey gear icon on your iPhone's home screen. If you don't see it there, it'll be in the Utilities folder in your app library.

steps.title: Tap Cellular.
steps.content: Tap Cellular . It's in the first group of options.

steps.title: Tap the "Cellular Data" switch to turn it on .
steps.content: Tap the "Cellular Data" switch to turn it on . If the switch was already on (green), skip this step.

steps.title: Scroll all the way down to "iCloud Drive."
steps.content: Scroll all the way down to "iCloud Drive." This option is at the bottom of the menu, past all of the other apps.

steps.title: Tap the "iCloud Drive" switch to turn it on .
steps.content: Tap the "iCloud Drive" switch to turn it on . This ensures that the data on your iCloud drive will continue to sync over your cellular when Wi-Fi is unavailable.

steps.title: Enable cellular data for other iCloud-related apps .
steps.content: Enable cellular data for other iCloud-related apps . Scroll back up to look at the other apps in the list. If an app's switch is green, that the app or service can use cellular when Wi-Fi is unavailable. If the switch is gray/white, it cannot. These are the iCloud-related apps and services for which you can enable cellular data: App Store Calendar Contacts Find My Keynote Mail Messages Music Notes Numbers Pages Photos Reminders
